title: UK in end-of-life care crisis as 100,000 people die each year without dignity
text:

Doctors warn Britain is in the grip of an end-of-life care crisis which subjects 100,000 people a year to an undignified death.

Campaigners say the NHS is battling a shortage of 3,500 nurses needed to support people dying at home.

Funding problems, meanwhile, forced the closure of a string of hospices which comfort and care for the terminally ill.

And around 80 per cent of hospices which rely on charity will fall into the red next year, says Hospices UK.

Dr Amy Proffitt, vice-president of The Association of Palliative Medicine, warned there are just 60 palliative care consultants – and a shortage of junior doctors training to specialise in the area.

(Image: Lorraine Ainsccow-Searle)

Dr Proffitt, a consultant at St Christopher’s Hospital in South London, said: “We wouldn’t run maternity services like this but are happy to allow the dying to rely on charity.

"Something has to change. We’ve 100,000 people a year who can’t access a hospice bed or even get the right care at home from specialist nurses.”

The crisis was highlighted when musician Angus Maclean, 58, died alone at home in May after an NHS hospice suspended its service.

His lonely death angered relatives who claim he was not given a dedicated nurse to check on him daily in the weeks before he died.

Angus, who played at Glastonbury, initially resisted hospice care after pancreatic cancer spread to his liver in March. Given just six months to live, he wanted to live out his final days at home in Hammersmith, West London.

(Image: Getty Images)

But his brother Donald, 57, said the family struggled to cope and Angus only received two visits from a district nurse.

Donald said: “There was no nursing team to help support him and his family so he didn’t die alone. We had no one to help us and him deal with dying.”

Angus did agree to move to a hospice five days before he died. But the 13-bed Pembridge ward at the nearby St Charles Centre had stopped ­taking patients last October.

Angus died at home the night before he was due to go to an alternative facility.

(Image: COLLECT UNKNOWN)

His friend Lorraine Ainscow-Searle, who is a ­former NHS ­psycho- therapist, said: “Angus was a lovely man. If we could have got him into a hospice bed even for a few days he wouldn’t have died the way he did. It is tragic to have someone die alone.”

A proposal to close Pembridge ward permanently is now under consideration. Anne Drinkall, an ex-NHS Community nurse and matron, is leading the fight to save it.

She said: “It is the poorest who suffer from NHS cuts and we are fighting hard to save Pembridge.”

Most hospices are funded by charities but some NHS units remain. An extra £25million funding was announced by the Government in August – a “drop in the ocean”, said Dr Proffitt.

The average adults hospice receives 30 per cent of funds from health budgets and the rest through charities, donation and ­fundraisers, according to Hospice UK.

For children’s hospices the State provides 22 per cent of funds. Last month St Mary’s Hospice in Ulverston, Cumbria, had to turn people away ­because it could not find a doctor to oversee its service.

Last week it was ­announced the 12-bed St Margaret’s Hospice in Yeovil will also close. And in January St Clare’s Hospice in Jarrow, Tyne and Wear, was forced into liquidation after 30 years.

Dr Proffitt says it costs £21million a year to help the dying at her unit alone.

She said: “Hundreds of millions are needed for a sector of health care that should be fully funded by the NHS.

(Image: Getty)

“We are not training enough junior doctors to become consultants – because the NHS won’t provide the funding. Not only will we not have the consultants we need in the future but we won’t have enough junior doctors to support existing consultants. Some hospices may close.”

An NHS spokesman for North West London expressed regret that Pembridge remains suspended, saying: “We are ­doing everything possible to mitigate the impact on patients, carers, families.

“We are working to improve services and reach a greater number of people. Hospices play a vital role which is why the NHS will more than double funding for children’s hospice and palliative care services over five years.”
description: EXCLUSIVE: Misery as more hospices across Britain are closed due to staff shortages
